theme: Love (Hearts / Couple / Wedding / Kiss / Romantic Scene / Something related to Valentines Day)

Cover with a pet on (The pet in question does not necessarily need to be a cat or dog, but I would steer away from wild animals such as polar bear. Although if there is a crime fiction novel involving a character who has a pet polar bear then prove me wrong!) [The 20th is Love Your Pet day]
Cover with a police officer on
Cover with a boat or ship on.
Cover related to Ireland (Celtic cross / Irish Flag / Shamrock / Scene which takes place in Ireland / Any other Irish symbol / A green cover) [This theme was chosen as it is St Patrick’s on the 17th]
Cover with a library or study on
Cover with a theatrical theme (Theatre / Playbill / Script / Actor / Footlights etc.)
Book which has the word ‘death’ in the title
Easter Monday (Chicks / Lambs / Cross / Hot cross buns / Easter eggs / Church etc.)
Cover with a gun on
Cover with a bloodstain (Preferably not a real one!)
Cover with fog or mist on
Anything royal on the cover (King / Queen / Crown / Palace / Other Symbols of a Monarchy) [This theme was chosen as it is King Charles III coronation on this day]
Cover with a doctor or nurse on
Cover with a skeleton on
Cover with footprints on
Cover with a fire on
Cover with a number in the title
Cover with a country house on
Cover with a blunt instrument on
Cover with a telephone on
Cover with a summer holiday theme (Holiday Resort/ Suitcase/ Sunbathers/ Beach/ Holidaymakers on a promenade or other holiday destination or facility – Be creative!)
Cover with someone in evening dress
Cover with a question in the title
Cover with an aeroplane on or another form of aerial transport
Cover with sports equipment on or with a sporting activity taking place
Cover with a London scene or landmark
Cover with a relative in the title (Aunt/ Uncle/ Father/ Mother/ Cousin etc.)
Cover with a bird of prey on
Cover with a scholastic/academic theme (School Pupils/ University Building/ School Bus/ Classroom/ Teacher etc.)
Cover with a date in the title (24th of ____ / June/ April Fool’s/ May-Week etc.)
Cover with a torch on
Cover with poison on
Cover with a train on
Cover with flowers on
Cover with a typewriter on
Cover with a single word title (i.e. a title which is only one word)
Cover with menacing hands on
Cover with an artist/ painting equipment on

It is my birthday so the theme is covers which include birthday imagery (Birthday balloons/party/presents/cake etc.). Alternatively if you cannot find a cover which fits this theme you can choose a cover for a mystery novel which was written by someone called Kate or has a main character called Kate (as you might have guessed by now my first name is Kate!)
Cover with insects on
Cover with a dagger/knife/sword on
Cover with a courtroom milieu (E.g. a dock, judge, gavel or jury etc.)
Cover with a pub or inn on
Cover with an alliterative title
Unsurprisingly it is a cover which has Christmas imagery on (E.g. Santa, Reindeer, Christmas (Fir) Trees, Presents, Christmas Dinner, Mistletoe etc.)
Cover for a first title in a mystery series.
Cover with a car on.
Cover with a scientific milieu e.g. a laboratory, a scientist or scientific equipment.
Cover with a direction in the title.
Cover with a river on.
Cover with a city on or in the title.
Cover with a WW2 setting.
Cover with a letter or parcel on.
Cover with the name of a body part in the title.

Cover for a mystery written by an author who is more famous for having written non-mystery stories. For example: A. A. Milne wrote the detective novel The Red House Mystery, but he is better known for his children stories concerning Winnie the Pooh.
Cover with a staircase on.
Cover with the name of a room in the title.
Cover with a shop on.
It’s April Fool’s Day so any crime fiction title which includes the words ‘April’ or ‘Fool’ in the title. Alternatively any crime fiction cover which shows a joke or a prank.
Cover for a mystery set in Asia.
Cover with a bridge on.
Cover with the name of the detective in the title.
Cover with a circus theme.
Cover with the word ‘secret’ in the title.
Cover with a rope or noose on.
Cover for a historical mystery (e.g. the book is set in a time period different to the one it was written in. For example Death Comes as the End by Agatha Christie is set in Ancient Egypt.)
Cover with a shape in the title (e.g. square, oval, circle, diamond, triangle).
Cover with a coffin on.
Cover for a mystery set in Australia.
Cover with a mountain on.
Cover with the name of a job in the title (e.g. secretary, builder, banker, writer etc.)
Cover with a camera or photo on.
Cover for a mystery whose title starts with the letter ‘J’.
Cover for a mystery set or published during the Victorian era.
Cover with an island on (or in the title).
Cover with a musical instrument on.
Cover for a mystery with an item of clothing in the title.
Cover with food on (or in the title).
Cover which is predominantly yellow.
Cover for a mystery with a widow in the title.
Cover with a space theme (or a title with space-themed words in) e.g. Moon, Rocket, Stars, Planets, Astronauts etc.
Cover for a mystery whose title alludes to another literary work. e.g. Night of the Jabberwock by Fredric Brown is alluding to Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland by Lewis Carroll.
Cover with a candle on (or in the title).
Cover with a key on (or in the title).
Cover with a drink on (or in the title).
Two crime fiction stories which share the same title (but are by different authors).
Cover with a chest or trunk on.
Crime fiction story written by two authors (they may or may not have a shared penname).
Cover with a mask on.
Cover which has a journalism theme e.g. newspaper, reporter, Fleet Street etc. (The reference can be in the title)
Cover which is predominantly purple.
Cover which has the name of the victim in the title.
Cover with a feeling/emotion in the title e.g. sad, lonely, fear, angry, jealous, happy etc.
Cover with a bell on (or in the title).
Cover with a financial theme e.g. bank, money, coins, currency references. (The reference can be in the title.)
Cover with something that can live in the sea/ocean e.g. crab, octopus, whale, shark etc. (The reference can be in the title).
Cover with a military rank in the title e.g. major, colonel, general, sergeant etc.
Cover with a magnifying glass on.
Cover which has a chess theme.
Same book, but different editions.
Cover which has a crossword on.
Cover with an umbrella on.
Crime fiction with a type of fabric in the title.
Title made up of two words.
Cover with playing cards on.
Crime fiction title with a unit of measurement in.
Last novel in a series.
Crime fiction title which includes a sound a human can make e.g. chuckle, scream, whistle, sing, shout, laugh, cry etc.
Cover with a writing implement on. (Not a typewriter)
Crime fiction title with a metal in.
Cover with a figure falling through the air.

Paired Opposites. A crime fiction title which contains one word which has its opposite meaning contained in a second crime fiction title. For example: Book 1: Put Out the Light by Ethel Lina White. Book 2: Step in the Dark by Ethel Lina White. The books can be written by different authors. Examples of opposites: Hot/Cold, Long/Short, Fat/Thin, Truth/Lie
Crime fiction set in Scotland.
Cover with a mirror on.
Crime fiction title including a word which denotes temperature e.g. hot, cold, freezing, boiling, heat, baking, warm, icy, chilly, cool, frosty etc.
Cover a smashed or broken object on.
Crime fiction title including a word which denotes a group of people e.g. gang, company, tribe, family, band etc.
Cover or title with a servant e.g. butler, maid, valet etc.
Crime fiction title with the word “suspicious” or “suspicion” in.
Cover or title which includes a shadow.
Crime fiction which has a character who is blind.
Crime fiction title which include an adverb of frequency e.g. constant, never, always, often, sometimes, every, seldom, rarely, frequently etc.
Cover with a monument/statue on.
Cover with a person who has facial hair e.g. beard, moustache etc.
Cover a jigsaw or jigsaw piece on.
Crime fiction title with a word denoting finality e.g. end, last, postscript, final, conclusion etc.
Cover or title with a gambling theme e.g. luck, fortune, dice, casino, bets, lottery etc.
Crime fiction novel which was published posthumously.
Cover with sunrise or sunset on.
Crime fiction title which begins with the words: “The Case of…”
Cover with a person wearing something red.
Crime fiction title with a type of terrain in the title e.g. desert, mountain, valley, swamp, plain etc.
Crime fiction title which includes a word to do with burglary e.g. theft, steal, robbery, heist, larceny etc.
Cover with an picture of a lamp/indoor lighting (not a torch).
Cover with someone sitting at a table or desk.
Cover or title which depicts or includes a road or highway.
Crime fiction with a film/TV studio setting.
Crime fiction with a place in the title e.g. county / region / country (Not a city)
Cover with a forest or woods on.
Cover which depicts smoking.
Crime fiction which includes a real life person in the story.
Cover with a bus.
Crime fiction whose title indicates potential risk e.g. uses words such as danger, warning, beware etc.
Crime fiction whose title starts with the phrase “The Man” or “The Woman”
Cover with a farm animal on e.g. cow, sheep, pig, chicken, horse.
Crime fiction which includes a characters who uses a wheelchair.
Crime fiction set in Wales.
Cover with a clock on.
Crime fiction title which hints that something has disappeared or is not visible.
Crime fiction with the words ‘day’ or ‘night’ in the title.
